comments: Plaintiff suffered catastrophic injuries when his tow truck was rear-ended by the defendant. Jury instructed that Ontario Drug Benefit Program should be treated as a contingency only, and no assignment to defendant of future SABS payments for medication, assistive devices, and services.

On appeal: Appeal allowed. The judgment was reduced by the sum of 44,583.90 to reflect an interest rate of 2.5% on the general damage award. The obligation to assign the income replacement benefits payable by RSA Insurance should continue until the respondent’s 64th birthday. The trial judge erred in failing to instruct the jury not to award any sum for drug benefits after plaintiff reached age 65 because from that age forward, he would suffer no loss as his drug claims would be covered by the Ontario Drug Benefit Program. The trial judge also erred in not ordering an assignment in relation to the awards for the cost of future medication and assistive devices and future professional services.
appeal_notes: Appeal allowed; judgment reduced by 44,583.90; interest rate adjusted to 2.5%; assignment obligations clarified.

The plaintiff’s reputation was key to her professional success and the defendant was intentionally malicious.

Defendant landlord called police multiple times on the plaintiff and pressed charges which were ultimately dismissed. Plaintiff spent time in detention centre, found the experience shocking and horrific, lost weight, hair turned white, health deteriorated, and reputation was damaged.

Defendant police officers conducted illegal search of Plaintiff’s home while he was out. Upon return, Plaintiff was falsely arrested and unlawfully detained. Court found Defendant’s Charter rights were violated, and damages flow from that injury.

comments: Appeal allowed in part. Sexual assault causing permanent mental and psychological trauma. Victim suffered severe lack of self-esteem, preventing her from pursuing education, and causing detachment from friends and family.
appeal_notes: Set aside on appeal

plaintiffs.name: Gill
injuries: Emotional distress and humiliation due to libellous statements
Loss of community standing and employment disruption

comments: Plaintiff alleged multiple libellous statements were made in three newspaper articles. Plaintiff was a prominent member of the Sikh community in Canada and Brampton. Comments had significant impact: he was driven from the community, left his employment for a period, and did not return to his usual life for at least two years. He still suffers from residual embarrassment and received no apology from defendants.
The defendant, an agent with a collection agency, made slanderous comments about the plaintiff to her bank manager. A jury awarded $40,000 in general damages. Appeal dismissed and award upheld.
appeal_notes: Appeal before Ont. S.C.J. (Div. Ct.) dismissed; award upheld.

comments: Libel action. Defendant made defamatory comments about the plaintiff on his blog. Aggravating factors included the plaintiff being a lawyer and the defendant also being a lawyer who should have known the impact of his comments.

Three plaintiffs, immigrants to Canada, operated a Punjabi language newspaper. The defendant, a competing newspaper, published a defamatory article alleging treasonous and terrorist activities. The article was untrue and no apology or retraction was issued.
case_name: Bains v. 1420546 Ontario Inc. (c.o.b. Niagara Weekly)

comments: Plaintiff treated by defendant psychiatrist for depression. Plaintiff claims negligence resulting in misdiagnosis responsible for subsequent manic episode. Plaintiff quit his job, left his wife and spent his savings during the manic episode. Standard of care by defendant was not breached nor was sufficient causation shown. Action dismissed.

plaintiffs.name: McClean
injuries: emotional distress due to unlivable home

other_damages.notes: Damages reduced by plaintiff’s failure to mitigate

comments: Defendant bought property next to the plaintiff’s house. The defendant’s excavation caused damage to the foundation of the plaintiff’s house rendering it unlivable for approximately two weeks. The backyard was also unusable for three months. Damages were somewhat reduced by the plaintiff’s failure to mitigate.

plaintiffs.name: Sarnelli
injuries: Emotional distress due to termination without notice

other_damages.description: Suggested award for defamation in the alternative

comments: Plaintiff was a locksmith who did work for the defendant company but was terminated without notice. The defendant’s contract made up two thirds of the plaintiff’s business. Plaintiff was awarded damages for wrongful termination because he should have received notice prior to termination. The lack of notice award is based on six months of the plaintiff’s per hour charge, materials he had acquired, previous work he had done for the defendant as well as his failure to mitigate. Action for defamation was dismissed due to lack of proof. In the alternative, $5,000 would be awarded as damages for defamation despite the fact that there is no evidence of loss. Aggravated damages were awarded due to humiliation and distress caused to the plaintiff while punitive damages were awarded because the defendant’s actions were high-handed and intended to take advantage of a vulnerable young woman.

defendant_name: Unknown (ER doctor, EMS attendants, nurses, family doctor)

other_damages.description: Past losses of deceased including financial support, counselling fees, funeral costs and household services
other_damages.notes: All discounted by 25% as contingencies for mortality and morbidity factors

comments: ER doctor failed to notice SARS form completed due to flu-like symptoms. EMS attendants failed to take deceased to hospital or take vital signs when he called 9-1-1 for shortness of breath. Liability apportioned 20/20/25/35 percent among nurses, EMS, family doctor, and ER doctor. Loss of support decreased because wife remarried.
case_name: Unknown (Deceased) v. Unknown (ER doctor, EMS attendants, nurses, family doctor)

other_damages.description: Cost of draining land using pumps, hoses and replacement of trees in backyard

comments: Plaintiff’s backyard flooded by defendant altering the grade of his backyard to redirect water drainage into plaintiff’s property. Defendant’s action constituted a nuisance. Non-pecuniary damages awarded for distress, inconvenience and interference with enjoyment of land.

injuries: Destruction of career, marriage, and reputation

comments: Re-trial to determine proper quantum of damages after remit by Court of Appeal. Defendant wrongfully dismissed Plaintiff, resulting in destruction of career, marriage, and reputation.
appeal_notes: Re-trial ordered after Court of Appeal remit

plaintiffs.name: Krawchuk
injuries: Emotional distress due to property defects

comments: After purchasing a home from the Defendant, Plaintiff discovered significant latent defects that required high repair costs. Plaintiff experienced stress and anxiety. Cross-appeal: Plaintiff argued real-estate agent should have been found liable. Defendant argued trial judge erred in finding liability on an unpleaded cause of action and that there was no duty of care.
appeal_notes: Cross-appeal by both parties regarding liability and duty of care.

plaintiffs.name: Mughal
injuries: Indignation due to unreasonably aggressive conduct

comments: Plaintiff was wrongfully detained and arrested by Defendant, a conservation officer, while hunting. Defendant came upon Plaintiff and asked to see his shotgun for inspection, purposely drawing out the inspection. Plaintiff suffered mental anguish and indignation due to unreasonably aggressive conduct by Defendant.
Defendant assaulted Plaintiff at a dinner party with a headbutt causing dental injuries, loss of consciousness, and embarrassment. Root canal required.

plaintiffs.name: Nicholson
injuries: Hepatitis C contracted from cut during professional wrestling match

comments: Defendant cut himself and plaintiff with the same blade during professional wrestling match. Plaintiff contracted Hepatitis C, causing WWE to revoke a professional wrestling contract.

plaintiffs.name: Awan

other_damages.description: Defendant posted defamatory statements about the Plaintiff

comments: Plaintiff was a law student and had difficulty finding a job as a result of defamatory statements made on Defendant’s blog.
appeal_notes: Defendant appealed. Appeal dismissed. [2017] I.L.R. para. G-2762, ONCA, K. Feldman J.A., Janet Simmons J.A., Paul Rouleau J.A.

plaintiffs.name: Strudwick
injuries: adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed moods

comments: Plaintiff was wrongfully dismissed because of hearing loss. She suffered from adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed moods caused by the manner of dismissal. Upon appeal, damages were increased to reflect permanent deafness and the defendant’s misconduct.
appeal_notes: Appeal allowed in part; damages increased on appeal (2016 ONCA 520).
case_name: Strudwick v. Applied Consumer & Clinical Evaluations Inc.

plaintiffs.name: Lucas
injuries: sexual abuse by clergy beginning at age 13

comments: Plaintiff was sexually abused by a member of the clergy beginning at age 13, resulting in PTSD, depression, anxiety, and long-term psychological and occupational impacts.

Plaintiff was hired by the Defendant’s company in 2002 and was quickly promoted to Vice President. Walmart eliminated the plaintiff’s position. The plaintiff was offered a position which was risky and included moral and aggravated damages.

other_damages.description: Annual salary she was receiving less salary paid
Wal-Mart’s portion of the health and dental benefits
Damages for the MIP in the amount she would have received for two years under the NCA
Additional damages for the MIP in the amount she would have received for two years under the NCA
Unpaid contribution or balance of the DPSP she was to have received for FYE 2011

comments: Plaintiff suffered traumatic neurosis and mental distress after termination from Wal-Mart. Action for breach of employment contract and post-termination conduct.

All five grounds of appeal dismissed. Trial judge’s comments about threshold regulation did not demonstrate bias. No error in admitting expert evidence or psychologist testimony. Family Law Act damages not excessive. Costs awards proportionate.
appeal_notes: Appeal dismissed on all grounds.

other_damages.description: Punitive damages for abuse by father
other_damages.notes: Awarded to each of the two twin sisters

comments: Physical, emotional and psychological abuse by father over 11 years during childhood. Serious effect on ability to engage with others and form relationships.
appeal_notes: Defendant appealed trial judge’s damage award; appeal dismissed. Plaintiff cross-appealed; dismissed for failure to prove psychiatric harm or entitlement to loss of competitive advantage.

defendant_name: The Estate of Kris Geoffrey Charlebois
comments: Plaintiff, younger brother of the defendant, suffered extended sexual abuse during youth. Defendant died before proceedings and was represented by estate trustee. Damages limited due to estate recovery limits. No claims for income loss or historical treatment expenses. Pre- and post-judgment interest awarded but unspecified.
case_name: Steven Charles Charlebois v. The Estate of Kris Geoffrey Charlebois

plaintiffs.name: Kardaras
injuries: Major depressive disorder with anxious features

other_damages.notes: Defendant ordered to pay benefit amount

comments: Primary issue was whether plaintiff was entitled to benefits under a group insurance policy arising from inability to work due to major depressive disorder with anxious features. Defendant breached duty of good faith.

plaintiffs.name: D.J.
injuries: Medical negligence at a maximum-security mental health hospital

comments: Medical negligence at a maximum-security mental health hospital.

Plaintiffs were treated with various experimental therapy programs involving high doses of hallucinogens, facilitated hallucinogenic encounters in a soundproof, windowless, brightly lit cell for periods up to eleven days, and strict physical discipline requiring patients to sit motionless for hours on a cold floor. Plaintiffs were restrained or strapped to each other.
appeal_notes: Liability decision

comments: Multiple male plaintiffs in their teens to 30s awarded varying non-pecuniary damages for traumatic neurosis; some received punitive damages.

comments: Social worker injured in motor vehicle accident. Developed chronic pain in multiple areas and headaches.

family_law_act_claims.description: Loss of Care, Guidance and Companionship

injuries: Death resulting from intentional missile strike on Flight PS 752

other_damages.description: Punitive damages awarded to each estate
other_damages.notes: Four plaintiffs sued; each estate received punitive damages

After a CBC article, she sued him, prompting a countersuit for defamation and malicious prosecution. They won an anti-SLAPP motion to dismiss. Plaintiff, on a fixed income, experienced significant stress.

comments: Plaintiffs, lawyers who previously represented the defendant, were defamed by him.

Plaintiff claimed damages for invasion of privacy after defendant police officer accessed her personal information linked to a murder suspect and falsely accused her of stalking via Facebook. Injuries included emotional distress from the false accusations and privacy violations. Court dismissed the claim; tort of intrusion upon seclusion not met.
case_name: D.S. v. H. Police Services Board

comments: Plaintiff sued defendant for trespass after a payment dispute. Brief use of driveway did not constitute trespass. Any emotional distress experienced by the plaintiff's wife was minimal, required no medical attention, and resolved within weeks. Court dismissed the claim.
Victim of unprovoked assault. Missed 1 week of work.

Plaintiff, an intoxicated and semi-conscious individual, was involved in an altercation with police officers and alleged assault leading to physical injuries and acute stress. Plaintiff failed to establish cause of action due to lack of credibility and unsubstantiated injuries. Had Plaintiff been credible, nominal damages would have been $2,500. Action dismissed as statute barred.
Plaintiff was arrested and suffered a blow to the head during arrest. Action dismissed. Damages assessed at $300.
Defendant threw a blood spotted paper towel at the plaintiff and punched him. Nominal damages awarded. Claim undefended.

Trial judge did not err in permitting an expert to rely on evidence from Statistics Canada. Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. The damages for loss of care, guidance and companionship under the Family Law Act were not excessive as to reflect an error in principle. Trial judge’s costs awards were proportionate.
